results.title: Louis Le Prince
results.brief_description: In 1888, French inventor Louis Le Prince used a single-lens camera to record the first motion pictures outside his home in Leeds. Though it lasted just two seconds, Roundhay Garden Scene was revolutionary.

constellations_primary.name: Painting pictures
constellations_primary.description: Painter and photographer Louis Le Prince was inspired to develop the technology to make animated pictures by the circular panoramic paintings of his friends. His films captured everyday life and alluded to his artistic vision for cinema.

results.description:
In 1888, French inventor Louis Le Prince used a single-lens camera to record the first motion pictures outside his home in Leeds. Though it lasted just two seconds, Roundhay Garden Scene was revolutionary. Le Prince prepared to exhibit his invention in New York in 1890, but before he got the chance he mysteriously disappeared from a train after visiting his brother in France.

Months later, American inventor Thomas Edison patented a camera suspiciously similar to Le Prince’s. While Edison was long rumoured to be involved in Le Prince’s disappearance, others believed Le Prince’s brother never took him to the train station. Because of his disappearance, Le Prince has been unfairly overlooked in cinema history.
description_for_label:
In 1888, French inventor Louis Le Prince used a single-lens camera to record the first motion pictures outside his home in Leeds. Though it lasted just two seconds, Roundhay Garden Scene was revolutionary. Le Prince prepared to exhibit his invention in New York in 1890, but before he got the chance he mysteriously disappeared from a train after visiting his brother in France.

Months later, American inventor Thomas Edison patented a camera suspiciously similar to Le Prince’s. While Edison was long rumoured to be involved in Le Prince’s disappearance, others believed Le Prince’s brother never took him to the train station. Because of his disappearance, Le Prince has been unfairly overlooked in cinema history.

results.title: Los Angeles riots
results.brief_description: The beating of Rodney King by the LAPD was caught on amateur videotape by George Holliday. Broadcast widely by news outlets, it’s arguably the first video of police brutality to go viral before the internet and was a catalyst for the Los Angeles riots in 1992.
results.description: The brutal beating of Rodney King by the LAPD was caught on amateur videotape by George Holliday. Broadcast widely by news outlets, it is arguably the first video of police brutality to go viral before the internet and the policemen’s acquittal was a catalyst for the Los Angeles riots in 1992. Five days into the rioting and social unrest, King himself appeared on TV, pleading with the public, “Can we all get along?”
description_for_label: The brutal beating of Rodney King by the LAPD was caught on amateur videotape by George Holliday. Broadcast widely by news outlets, it is arguably the first video of police brutality to go viral before the internet and the policemen’s acquittal was a catalyst for the Los Angeles riots in 1992. Five days into the rioting and social unrest, King himself appeared on TV, pleading with the public, “Can we all get along?”

results.title: Los Angeles riots
results.brief_description: The beating of Rodney King by the LAPD was caught on amateur videotape by George Holliday. Broadcast widely by news outlets, it’s arguably the first video of police brutality to go viral before the internet and was a catalyst for the Los Angeles riots in 1992.

constellations_other.name: Rodney King LA Riots
constellations_other.description: The brutal beating of Rodney King by the LAPD was caught on amateur videotape and became what is arguably the first video of police brutality to go viral before the internet. It was a catalyst for the 1992 LA riots, which has influenced media ever since.

results.description: The brutal beating of Rodney King by the LAPD was caught on amateur videotape by George Holliday. Broadcast widely by news outlets, it is arguably the first video of police brutality to go viral before the internet and the policemen’s acquittal was a catalyst for the Los Angeles riots in 1992. Five days into the rioting and social unrest, King himself appeared on TV, pleading with the public, “Can we all get along?”

Broadcast widely by news outlets, it is arguably the first video of police brutality to go viral before the internet and the policemen’s acquittal was a catalyst for the Los Angeles riots in 1992. Five days into the rioting and social unrest, King himself appeared on TV, pleading with the public, “Can we all get along?”

results.title: Lois Weber
results.brief_description: Lois Weber was one of the most daring filmmakers of Hollywood’s silent era. A leading director, screenwriter, producer and actor, she helped establish the use of split-screens to show simultaneous action in her 1913 film Suspense, and she experimented with synchronised sound.

constellations_primary.name: Lois Weber and the split-screen
constellations_primary.description: Lois Weber was the third filmmaker to use split screens to show simultaneous action, helping establish it as part of cinematic language, particularly its use in thrillers. It's since been taken to extremes by auteurs and videogames.

results.description:
Lois Weber was one of the most daring filmmakers of Hollywood’s silent era. A leading director, screenwriter, producer and actor, she helped establish the use of split-screens to show simultaneous action in her 1913 film Suspense, and she experimented with synchronised sound. In an estimated 200 to 400 films, Weber explored social issues such as poverty, capital punishment, drug abuse and abortion. Her controversial film Hypocrites (1915) featured the first full-frontal nude scene.

“She writes her own stories and continuity, selects her cast, directs the pictures, plans to the minutest detail all the scenic effects, and, finally, titles, cuts and assembles the film. Few men have assumed such responsibility.” – Aline Carter, Motion Picture, 1921
description_for_label:
Lois Weber was one of the most daring filmmakers of Hollywood’s silent era. A leading director, screenwriter, producer and actor, she helped establish the use of split-screens to show simultaneous action in her 1913 film Suspense, and she experimented with synchronised sound. In an estimated 200 to 400 films, Weber explored social issues such as poverty, capital punishment, drug abuse and abortion. Her controversial film Hypocrites (1915) featured the first full-frontal nude scene.

“She writes her own stories and continuity, selects her cast, directs the pictures, plans to the minutest detail all the scenic effects, and, finally, titles, cuts and assembles the film. Few men have assumed such responsibility.” – Aline Carter, Motion Picture, 1921

results.title: Living Pictures Cinematograph: Clown
results.brief_description: A flipbook / flick book of twenty-six pages designed in such a way that when flicked it creates a sense of movement, in this example, a clown tips his hat. Small outer corners lost from front cover.

results.title: Living on Velvet cinema slide
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures and Frank Borzage
results.credit_line: ACMI has endeavoured to contact the owners of these objects since their deposit in 2015. Unfortunately this has been unsuccessful. We would welcome any information to identify the owners.
results.brief_description: Glass Cinema slide which has the slide imagery with a monochromatic emulsion that has then been hand painted with coloured pigments or dye. TEXT on the slide reads: Go gloriously mad with the Vagabond Trio Kay Francis Living on Velvet with Warren William & George Brent Not suitable for general exhibition.
results.description: Glass Cinema slide which has the slide imagery with a monochromatic emulsion that has then been hand painted with coloured pigments or dye.
